questions.text: A 56-year-old woman visits an outpatient clinic. She was concerned because she had discovered a lump in her right breast. Palpation revealed irregular nodularity. Mammography reveals varying densities in both breasts. A needle biopsy of a breast lesion is shown (see image below). An excisional biopsy of the contralateral breast reveals similar histology. Which of the following pathologic diagnoses is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Aspect Description
Definition Lobular Carcinoma In Situ (LCIS) is a non-invasive condition where abnormal cells are found in the lobules (milk-producing glands) of the breast. It is not considered a true cancer but rather a marker of increased breast cancer risk.
Characteristics - Abnormal cells are confined to the milk-producing lobules and do not breach the basement membrane.
  - Often discovered incidentally during breast biopsies for other reasons.
Risk and Progression LCIS is considered a risk factor for developing invasive breast cancer, but not all cases progress. Women with LCIS have a higher risk of developing breast cancer in either breast.
Symptoms LCIS itself does not cause symptoms. It's usually discovered through mammograms, biopsies, or other imaging studies.
Diagnosis - Mammography and other imaging techniques to identify abnormalities
  - Biopsy to confirm presence of abnormal cells and rule out invasive cancer
Treatment LCIS doesn't require aggressive treatment on its own, as it's not cancer. However, close monitoring and risk reduction strategies are recommended.
Management - Regular mammograms and breast exams
  - Discussion of risk factors with healthcare provider
  - Consideration of risk-reducing medications (e.g., tamoxifen) for high-risk patients
  - Lifestyle modifications (healthy diet, exercise)

questions.text: The medical officer arrives to examine the 22-year-old woman who had been brought in unconscious with a blood-soaked cloth tied around her left wrist. She was allegedly found by her roommate in a pool of blood with a kitchen knife lying next to her in the bathroom of their dorm. On examination, the doctor notes the presence of multiple shallow incision wounds extending from the lateral to the medial aspect indicating hesitation when making the cuts . These will be documented as evidence to support which type of wounds??
questions.explanation:
Trait Suicide Homicide Accident
Nature of wounds Usually incised and stab Usually chop wounds, lacerations and stab Usually lacerations, abrasions and contusions
Number of wounds Multiple Multiple Usually single, may be multiple
Target area Accessible parts only, i.e., front and sides of the body, such as neck, wrists, left side of chest, groin, etc. No fixed site; vital parts, such as head, chest, abdomen. Anywhere; usually on exposed parts and bony prominences. Number of wounds on the same side.
Wound grouping Arranged Irregular Vulnerable parts
Direction In right-handed persons from left to right and from above downwards Any direction Any direction
Severity Mostly superficial; one or two deep wounds Mostly severe and extensive Variable severity
Hesitation marks Usually present Absent Absent
Defence wounds Absent May be present Absent
Secondary injuries Absent May be connected with fight May be associated with accident
Weapon By the side of the body or may be grasped firmly due to cadaveric spasm Absent Present
Clothes Not damaged as they are usually removed May be damaged May be damaged and stained with oil, grease, mud, dirt, etc
Scene of crime Usually inside closed room; no disturbances of surroundings. Disturbed and disorderly with signs of struggle and blood stains. Varies with the nature of the accident
Motive Present, such as domestic worries, disappointment in love, chronic disease, failure in examination, etc Revenge, robbery, sexual offences Absent

The doctor notices that the lips and tongue are swollen and blackish. The teeth appear chalky white and the injuries are limited to the upper respiratory and digestive tract. The doctor is aware of the characteristics of acid burns. Which one of the following is true of an acid burn?

options.label: D
options.text: Greater risk of severe systemic toxicity

questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Learning Objective
  • ➤ Alkalines cause saponification followed by liquefaction necrosis and, in general, penetrate more deeply and carry a greater risk of severe systemic toxicity. In acid ingestion, local symptoms are more severe than systemic symptoms. Acids produce coagulative necrosis, precipitate proteins with resultant hard eschar or scab (which may protect the underlying tissue from further damage), have no remote action and act as irritants when slightly diluted, but as stimulants when well diluted. Acids usually causes second degree, deep partial thickness burns, tend to be clearly demarcated and are dry, hard and mildly edematous.

questions.text: The body of a 45-year-old male with a known history of HIV infection has been sent for postmortem investigations . What is the best method of organ removal in the autopsy of this case ?
questions.explanation:
Autopsy Techniques   Advantage Disadvantage
Letulle’s

Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed "en masse," as one big organ block.
  • The best technique to see relations amongst organs.
  • Preferred in infants so that congenital abnormalities in different organs can be seen in relation to each other
  • Rapid technique
 Difficult to handle large mass.

Ghon’s

Cervical, thoracic abdominal and pelvic organs are removed in separate blocks (en block)

 This method can also be used in Infants  

Virchow’s

Organs are removed one by one

 Most commonly used technique (easier to perform) Anatomical relations of organs are not preserved
Rokitansky In situ dissection (inside the body itself)

Good for

  • Infected bodies like HIV, and Hepatitis B (prevents spreading of infection)
  • Radiation hazards
  • Fetal brain dissection

Hamate 3 months- 1 year
Scaphoid 5 years

questions.correct_answer: A. Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory acidosis

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), hyperlipidemia, hypertension, diabetes, and 10 days of progressively increasing dyspnea with exertion presented. Thoracocentesis was performed after a chest scan revealed a significant left pleural effusion . Which of the following is not part of the criteria used to distinguish between exudate and transudate?

options.label: B
options.text: Pleural fluid lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)/serum LDH ratio > 0.6

options.label: C
options.text: Pleural fluid LDH level > two-thirds the upper limit of the laboratory’s reference range of serum LDH

options.label: D
options.text: Pleural fluid sugar < 2/3rd of blood sugar

questions.correct_answer: D. Pleural fluid sugar < 2/3rd of blood sugar
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Option
  • ↳ Effusion LDH level greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of the laboratory's reference range of serum LDH is a Light criterion for exudative effusion. LDH leaks from damaged cells and combines with the effusion. A high LDH value in the effusion is a sign of damaged cells, which usually result from an exudative process.
  • ↳ Effusion LDH level greater than two-thirds of the upper limit of the laboratory's reference range of serum LDH is a Light criterion for exudative effusion.
  • ↳ LDH leaks from damaged cells and combines with the effusion. A high LDH value in the effusion is a sign of damaged cells, which usually result from an exudative process.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented to you with complaints of nausea, vomiting, yellowish discolouration of skin, and sclera. He also had complaints of low-grade fever associated with right upper quadrant pain for the past 1 week. Initial investigations were done. He is found to have HBsAg positive and HBeAg positive . Which of the following test is useful to estimate the severity of acute hepatitis?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Male and female aged 45 years and older: 8-38 units/L or 8-38 international units (IU)/L (SI units) Female younger than age 45 years: 5-27 units/L or 5-27 IU/L (SI units) Elderly: Slightly higher than adult level Child: Similar to adult level Newborn: Five times higher than adult level
  • ↳ Male and female aged 45 years and older: 8-38 units/L or 8-38 international units (IU)/L (SI units)
  • ↳ Female younger than age 45 years: 5-27 units/L or 5-27 IU/L (SI units)
  • ↳ Elderly: Slightly higher than adult level
  • ↳ Child: Similar to adult level
  • ↳ Newborn: Five times higher than adult level
  • ↳ Option D: Alkaline phosphatase
  • ↳ Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels are usually in the reference range but may elevate to no higher than twice the normal level. If ALP is elevated significantly, consider liver abscess or biliary obstruction.
  • ↳ Alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels are usually in the reference range but may elevate to no higher than twice the normal level. If ALP is elevated significantly, consider liver abscess or biliary obstruction.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman presents in the hospital with complaints of painful joints in the hands. She also complained of morning stiffness associated with a decrease in the intensity of the pain after physical activity. On examination, a decrease in the range of movement and a weakening in hand grip and strength along with trigger fingers were noticed. Which of the following would be the earliest radiological change in such patients?

A 4-year-old boy, adequately vaccinated according to his age, was brought to emergency with a 3-day history of fever, rash, irritability , and poor feeding. After a few days, the baby developed non-purulent conjunctiviti s and foot edema . Her mother also complained of his tongue turning into a deep red tongue and appearing swollen. A differential diagnosis of Kawasaki disease was made. What is the cardinal feature of Kawasaki disease apparent on blood reports?

A 46-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department by her home health aide secondary to her behaving in a disorganized manner, including yelling, cursing, and throwing belongings out of the window. Moreover, she has a 20-year-old history of focal impaired awareness with cognitive changes and behavioural arrest, progressing to poorly controlled bilateral tonic-clonic seizures . Subsequently, her Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) displays asymmetry of the hippocampus , with a prominent right temporal horn of the lateral ventricle . Based on the history and findings, what is the most probable diagnosis in her case?

A 34-year-old woman presents in the emergency department following a fall from a height. The patient complains of severe headache, vomiting, and blurred vision. Glasgow coma scale score is 13/15, blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg, and heart rate is 110 beats/min. A raised intracranial pressure is suspected. Which of the following treatment options is the most effective way of reducing ICP?

A 65-year-old female comes to the neurology clinic with dysphagia. There is also loss of taste on the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue. There is no history of muscle weakness, dyspnea or diplopia. The woman is diabetic and hypertensive. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg, and her pulse is 70 beats/min . On physical examination, when the right side of the pharynx is touched with a tongue blade, the palate elevates symmetrically. When the left side of the pharynx is touched, the palate does not elevate at all. Which of the following cranial nerves is most likely to be responsible for this condition ?
questions.explanation:
Right Side Left Side
A:⊕ 9th A:×
E:⊕ 10th E:⊕ 10th

questions.text: A 70-year-old male presented to your clinic with features of typical Parkinsonism. He is noted to have short shuffling steps, stooped posture, and absent automatic arm swing. He is having a good response to levodopa. Which of the following would have been the earliest symptom of Parkinsonism in this patient?

A 30-year-old male comes to OPD complaining of worsening malaise, body weakness, abdominal pain, and dark urine for 1 day . He has had a past medical history of a carbuncle on his buttock, for which he received cotrimoxazole 3 days before. On physical examination, he is icte ric with normal vital signs. Investigations reveal that haemoglobin has fallen from 14.4 g/dL to 9.1 g/dL, and his bilirubin has risen from normal to 3.5 mg/dL , urine dipstick is positive for bilirubin . A peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. What may be the most common cause of death regarding this patient's condition?

A middle-aged chronic alcoholic man complains of a burning sensation in the mouth. On examination, he has thickened, dry, smooth tongue without the filiform papillae. Mean corpuscular volume(MCV) is 100 fl. Which of the following should be the first line of approach in the management of this patient?
questions.correct_answer: A. Estimation of Vitamin B12 levels
questions.explanation:
Vitamin B12 deficiency
  • Macrocytic anaemia (MCV> 100fl)
  • Bilateral peripheral neuropathy or degeneration (demyelination) of the cervical and thoracic posterior and lateral (pyramidal) tracts of the spinal cord.

Symptoms

  • Anorexia → weight loss
  • Diarrhoea or constipation.
  • Glossitis
  • Angular cheilosis
  • Jaundice (unconjugated)
  • Reversible melanin skin hyperpigmentation
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • The anaemia and low leukocyte count may predispose to infections, particularly of the respiratory and urinary tracts.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male, a known case of type-2 diabetes mellitus for the past 20 years with poor glycaemic control, presents to the local clinic with complaints of passing foamy urine . He has a 25-pack-a-year smoking history and drinks half a bottle of alcohol daily. Vital signs show pulse 88 beats/minute, blood pressure 160/90mmHg and respiratory rate 12 breaths/minute . After further workup, a diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy is confirmed. Which of the following would be the earliest finding that can confirm the diagnosis of diabetic nephropathy?

Tony Stark is a 45-year-old male who was referred by his primary care physician after presenting to the ER with difficulty in breathing. Tony's physician was unable to find a medical explanation for his symptoms, which left Tony feeling confused, stressed, and angry. Over the last 6 months, Tony has had several instances where he felt an intense fear that would reach a peak within a few minutes. During these instances, he would also experience sweating, heart palpitations, chest pain and discomfort, and shortness of breath. Tony began to rely on his wife for even small things as to drive their children to their various activities. She was understanding but she is worried about her husband. His Doctor Jarvis diagnosed Tony to have panic attacks. Which of the following symptoms she can be least worried about her husband?

Despite 5 years of psychiatric treatment, a 25-year-old female university graduate patient presents to an outpatient clinic with symptoms that have not resolved. She cries during the psychiatric interview, complaining of not being able to explain herself and being unable to socialize with others. During her mental evaluation, she said something interesting: "There were occasions when I laughed for no reason, but I suppose that wasn't very healthy." Which of the following is the benefit of ECT in the case of Manic-Depressive Psychosis?

A 40-year-old patient had the peculiar symptom of feeling as if he were living in the time of ancient monarchs many years ago, and sometimes even several centuries ago. He claimed that he felt transported to a location several centuries ago, during the reign of Raja Raja Cholan. He had the impression that he was the king, and that he could see everything around him, even ancient structures, but he was unable to respond to the situation. He noticed the present after a few minutes. This is an example of an Oneiroid state, which is defined as follows:

Diana is a 25-year-old woman who presents with a history of non-suicidal self-injury, specifically cutting her arms and legs, since she was a teenager. She has made two suicide attempts by overdosing on prescribed medications, one as a teenager and one six months ago; she also reports chronic suicidal ideation, explaining that it gives her relief to think about suicide as a “way out.”. She describes a longstanding pattern of changing her hobbies, style of clothing. At times, she thinks that her partner is “the best thing that’s ever happened to me” and will impulsively buy him lavish gifts however, at other times she admits to thinking “I can’t stand him ” .Which of the following therapies is effective for her?

A 44-year-old premenopausal woman recently diagnosed with breast cancer presents with a lump in her breast and further investigation established a diagnosis of HER-2 negative, ER-negative, and PR-negative invasive early breast cancer. Partial mastectomy was done to remove the tumor and advised to receive 6 cycles of chemotherapy. Which of the following is the best chemotherapy regimen for this patient?
questions.explanation:
New Drugs in CA Breast
Ixabepilone
  • Used for anthracycline and taxane resistant breast cancer
Lapatinib
  • Inhibitor of Her-2-neu and EGFR tyrosine kinase
  • Second-line Her-2-neu therapy
Sunitinib
  • Approved for advanced renal cancer and refractory metastatic breast cancer

questions.text: A 29-year-old male presents to the surgery OPD complaining of swelling on the right side of the neck for the last 6 months. He is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 130/70 mmHg, a pulse rate of 86 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute. His neck examination reveals a solid mass on the right side of his neck. A thyroid scan reveals the following finding, shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 71-year-old male was referred to the surgery department by his family physician for an incidental finding of a gallstone. The patient denied any abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or jaundice. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?

A 54-year-old male presents with complaints of dysphagia and hematemesis. He has a long history of smoking and alcohol consumption. He is a known case of advanced carcinoma esophagus and is on palliative chemotherapy. What is the common site of the CA esophagus for this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: The lower end of the esophagus

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most likely related to postoperative ileus ?

options.label: A
options.text: The use of intravenous patient-controlled analgesia does not affect the return of small bowel motor activity

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of peritonitis at the time of the original operation delays the return of normal bowel function

options.label: C
options.text: The routine use of metoclopramide will hasten the return of small intestinal motor activity

options.label: D
options.text: Contrast radiographic studies have no role in distinguishing early postoperative bowel obstruction from normal ileus

questions.correct_answer: B. The presence of peritonitis at the time of the original operation delays the return of normal bowel function

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the gastroenterologist with complaints of diarrhoea for more than one month and colicky abdominal pain for five days. On examination, the patient is a thin and lean man with a blood pressure of 115/70 mmHg and a heart rate of 80 beats per minute. The doctor has advised a few blood tests and a colonoscopy , which indicate the diagnosis of ulcerative colitis . Which of the following findings is consistent with the above diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: The disease is confluent, there are no skip areas in the colon, and the rectum is involved

options.label: C
options.text: The full thickness of the bowel wall is involved

options.label: D
options.text: Microscopic examination of the mucosa reveals granulomas

questions.correct_answer: B. The disease is confluent, there are no skip areas in the colon, and the rectum is involved
questions.explanation:
Ulcerative Colitis (UC)  
Wall involvement Mucosal and submucosal ulcers
Location Begins in the rectum and can extend proximally up to the cecum, the remainder of the GI tract is unaffected
Symptoms Left lower quadrant pain (rectum) with bloody diarrhea
Inflammation Crypt abscesses with neutrophils
Gross appearance Pseudopolyps; loss of haustra 
Complications Toxic megacolon and carcinoma (risk is based on the extent of colonic involvement and duration of disease, generally no a concern until >10 years of disease)

questions.text: A patient with steroid-resistant ITP underwent laparoscopic splenectomy. On day 2 of the postoperative period, the patient had fever episodes . Which of the following scenarios is most likely?

A 45-year-old man presents in the outpatient department with the complaint of painful swelling of the scrotum and feeling of pressure at the base of the penis. The physical examination reveals that there is a mass on one side of the testicle . The vitals are within normal limits. The sign is shown in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

A 74-year-old man with chronic kidney disease stage 3A who has developed a decline in glomerular filtration rate (GFR) after the initiation of warfarin therapy due to atrial fibrillation is referred for dialysis. The patient has been admitted and is prepared to initiate dialysis . What is the pathophysiological effect of creating an AV fistula?

A 48-year-old male comes to the physician 3 months after noticing skin changes on his scalp. When he scrapes off the crust of the lesion, it reappears after a few days. Occasionally, his scalp itches or he notices a burning sensation . He had a mole removed on his right forearm 5 years ago . He is a retired postman. Examination shows a single rough patch on his scalp. A photograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 63-year-old man with a history of anterior myocardial infarction, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension visits the doctor after experiencing shortness of breath, low-grade fever, excessive night sweats, and significant weight loss. His vital signs include a temperature of 38.0°C (100.4°F), a pulse of 104/min. Examination shows a painless fluctuant, non-transilluminate swelling on the neck with a thin watery discharge, as shown in the image below: Chest x-ray shows bilateral pleural effusion and patchy infiltrates in the right middle lobe of the lung. Which of the following is the most likely clinical diagnosis for this patient?

A 2-year-old boy presented with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain with distension, bilious vomiting, and fever for 3 weeks . He weighed 8 kg with a history of failure to thrive since early infancy . The abdomen was mildly distended with non-tender hepatomegaly. The chest radiograph was normal. USG suggested dilated large bowel loops that were peristaltic with moderate free fluid . The child was kept nil per oral and the fluid and electrolyte imbalance was corrected. Due to persistent bilious aspirates, an upper gastrointestinal (GI) contrast study was performed that suggested malrotation with sigmoid volvulus. The patient was scheduled for surgery. Which of the following is a component of the procedure ?

options.label: A
options.text: Reduction of volvulus by clockwise rotation

options.label: B
options.text: Ladd's band divided near the medial aspect of the duodenum

options.label: D
options.text: Part of the jejunum is resected and anastomosis performed

questions.correct_answer: A. Reduction of volvulus by clockwise rotation
questions.explanation:
Cecal Volvulus

Sigmoid Volvulus

Obstruction point

Right Lower quadrant

Pelvis

Shape

Fairly straight loop of dilated colon from RLQ to LUQ

Curved/folded loop of dilated colon with apex pointing to the pelvis (“twist-tie” appearance)

Haustral markings?

Often

Rarely

Number of obstructing points?

One (Just distal to cecum)

Two-distal sigmoid colon + Proximal sigmoid colon-ie CLOSED LOOP OBSTRUCTION + distal colon obstruction

Haustral markings?

Often

Rarely

Air Fluid levels?

One

Two or more

Distal colon

Collapsed due to proximal colon obstruction

Dilated due to distal colon obstruction

questions.text: A 55-year-old male, a watchman by occupation, comes to the OPD complaining of swelling and bulging of veins in the lower limbs . He also describes feeling restlessness, occasional cramping bilaterally, and tiredness at the end of the day . E xamination reveals dilated, tortuous veins in the patient's right lower limb, extending from the middle thigh to the leg in a standing position. Doppler test results show venous stasis. On the basis of the patient's condition, which of the following is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Most common symptom: Dull aching pain in the veins after prolonged standing the whole day

options.label: B
options.text: Clinical investigation is the choice for the diagnosis of varicose veins

options.label: C
options.text: Bisgard's Regime is not used for venous ulcers

options.label: D
options.text: Trendelenberg operation is a gold standard treatment for varicose veins

questions.correct_answer: A. Most common symptom: Dull aching pain in the veins after prolonged standing the whole day

questions.text: A 36-year-old African-American male presents to a plastic surgeon with a recurrent keloid lesion in the left earlobe with previous injuries. The lesion was operated on but always grows back postoperatively. On examination, the patient has a 2 cm non-tender swelling anterior to his tragus. The most appropriate management of recurrent keloid is?
questions.correct_answer: B. Intramarginal excision followed by radiation

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a history of road traffic accidents due to a motorcycle collision with a heavy vehicle. Vitals are within normal limits. On abdominal examination, no guarding or rigidity is found, although the patient has mild tenderness in the left hypochondrium . A focused assessment with sonography in trauma is done, and the findings are shown in the image below: Which of the following does it suggest?
questions.explanation:
Subxiphoid transverse viewQ

• Assess pericardial sacQ

Right upper quadrant (RUQ) longitudinal viewQ

• Assess perihepatic regionQ

Left upper quadrant (LUQ) longitudinal viewQ

• Assess perisplenic regionQ

Suprapubic longitudinal & transverse viewQ

• Assess pelvisQ
  • e-FAST (extended FAST) has two additional views, right & left thoracic views to rule out pneumothorax or hemothoraxQ.

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman presented with an enlarging lesion on the upper back of 3 years duration. She had multiple co-morbidities. On examination, there was a 4-cm diameter erythematous, shiny plaque. A punch biopsy showed superficial basal cell carcinoma. It was decided to treat her with imiquimod. What is the recommended treatment regimen?
questions.correct_answer: B. 5 times per week for 6 weeks
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Imiquimod is a synthetic imidazoquinolone amine with a potent immune response modifier activity. This characteristic property of imiquimod has led to its use in several applications in dermatology, especially in cutaneous malignancies like superficial BCC, where it is effective and safe. Imiquimod is used 5 times per week for 6 weeks in BCC.
  • ➤ Imiquimod is a synthetic imidazoquinolone amine with a potent immune response modifier activity. This characteristic property of imiquimod has led to its use in several applications in dermatology, especially in cutaneous malignancies like superficial BCC, where it is effective and safe. Imiquimod is used 5 times per week for 6 weeks in BCC.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with hematemesis, melena, and mild splenomegaly. There is no obvious jaundice or ascites . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old chronic alcoholic female presented with complaints of pain in the epigastric region and multiple episodes of vomiting. The patient was admitted and diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis after an extensive evaluation. The patient had severe abdominal pain, which did not resolve with medical therapy. Which of the following Nerve block helps relieve pain in this patient?

A 23-year-old female with tenderness in the right iliac fossa is being prepared for an exploratory laparotomy. The specimen from the surgery is given below. What gold standard investigation is used to diagnose this condition before surgery in doubtful cases?

A 40-year-old male presents to the neurology department with complaints of severe headache associated with blurred vision and vomiting for the last 1 hour. He is afebrile, has a blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg, a pulse rate of 47 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 27 breaths per minute . His GCS is 12/15, and he has classical features of Cushing's Triad. His MRI brain reveals a posterior fossa lesion leading to raised intracranial pressure. What would be the management of the raised ICP in this case ?

A woman in her early 20s was referred for neurological examination due to slowly progressive wasting of the small hand muscles and weakness of the left hand. She also had a history of being treated for a left-arm fracture some 2yrs ago. The patient had always been healthy, with no known family history of neurological disease. She described reduced fine motor skills and difficulty writing because she struggled to grip the pen. This was not accompanied by pain or loss of sensation. She had not seen any signs of functional decline in the proximal musculature of the arms or in the lower extremities. The probable nerve injury involved in this patient would be?

A 58-year-old man presents in the hospital with dull pain for 8 months. A round tender mass is present on the right knee. On x-ray, a sunburst pattern of the osteolytic bone lesion is found in the combination of sclerotic bone formation and invasion of surrounding tissues. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?

A 48-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after encountering a road traffic accident. He was a non-restrained driver in a car. He got hit by a truck from the side, and the car rolled over. The patient has painful neck movements and left finger numbness and weakness. A neck collar is applied, and a CT scan is ordered. The CT scan image of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most likely fracture?

options.label: C
options.text: Due to fracture of traumatic spondylolisthesis of C2 over C3

questions.text: A 5-day-old newborn baby is admitted to the hospital in an agonal state with pale mucosa and acute respiratory failure. The child's mother did not have a prenatal follow-up. She reports the non-existence of disease in the family. An X-ray of the child is given below. Which of the following is not true about the given condition?
questions.explanation:

Onset at preschool age (Tarda); hearing loss; involvement of

teeth (type I.A. only)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department after he fell while playing football and hit his right elbow. Physical examination reveals severe pain and tenderness in his elbow with a limited range of motion. An x-ray was performed that showed a fracture of the medial epicondyle of the right humerus. Which is the most common nerve injured in the given clinical scenario?
questions.explanation:
Injury Common Nerve Involvement
Anterior or inferior shoulder dislocation Axillary (circumflex humeral) nerve
Fracture surgical neck humerus Axillary nerve
Fracture shaft humerus Radial nerve
Supracondylar fracture of humerus Median nerve
Medial epicondyle humerus Ulnar nerve
Monteggia fracture (proximal ulna) dislocation Posterior interosseous nerve
Volkman’s ischemic contracture Anterior Interosseous nerve
Lunate dislocation Median nerve
Hip dislocation Sciatic nerve
Knee dislocation Common peroneal nerve

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents to the surgical Outpatient department. His CT scan reveals carcinoma of the head of the pancreas . It is decided to carry out a Whipple's procedure . What will be the replacement fluid required per hour?

A 10-year-old male child who is in a case of acute appendicitis is posted for an emergency appendectomy. His medical history is consistent with bronchial asthma. His medication includes an albuterol inhaler. Last week, he suffered from a cough and fever with yellow sputum, which is now better. Which of the following agent must be avoided in this patient?

A 55-year-old male is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. He had a traumatic brain injury due to a road traffic accident. The primary survey showed unconsciousness with a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg and a pulse rate of 50 beats/minute. He was posted for emergency decompressive craniotomy under general anaesthesia. The intravenous anaesthetic agent to be avoided in this patient will be?

A 4-year-old child came to the emergency operation theatre for the removal of the aspirated foreign body with the aid of rigid bronchoscopy. During the removal of the foreign body, spontaneous ventilation was maintained with a smaller-sized endotracheal tube. Which among the following is the ideal anaesthetic circuit for this case?

A 5-year-old child presents in the outpatient department with a history of frequent micturition , pain while urinating and low-grade fever for five days. He has had recurrent episodes of similar symptoms for the last few years. Physical examination is normal. Which of the following should be used to visualise any congenital defect in this patient?

A 55-year-old male, a known case of diabetes mellitus type-2, presents to the emergency department with complaints of mild abdominal pain over the left side of the abdomen for the last 2 days. He has had a history of bloody diarrhoea for the last 5 days. On examination, abdominal tenderness is present. A plain X-ray abdomen is advised; this shows a thumbprint sign. Based on the above-given findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?

A full-term neonate is born by elective cesarean to a gravida II woman. Respiratory distress is reported soon after birth, for which the infant requires NICU admission. Antenatal ultrasound shows polyhydramnios, shortening of proximal limbs, and a large head. The neonate at birth had typical features of achondroplasia, like short proximal limbs, a large head, and a depressed nasal bridge. Based on perinatal history, clinical features, and investigations, a diagnosis of achondroplasia is made. Which of the following is NOT a feature of this condition?
A patient from the northeast presented with respiratory distress. An NCCT was advised, which reveals a large cystic double-walled lesion. What is the diagnosis?

A 28-year-old female, G3P2, presents to the labour room due to painful uterine contractions and vaginal bleeding at 35 weeks of gestation. Her blood pressure is 160/100mmHg, and her pulse is 100/min. Physical examination reveals uterine tenderness. Per vaginal examination reveals, cervical dilatation of 2cm with bright red bloody discharge. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the patient’s presentation?
questions.explanation:
Class 0: Asymptomatic
  • Diagnosis is made retrospectively by finding an organized blood clot or depressed area on a delivered placenta.
Class 1: Mild (48%)
  • Bleed seen only after delivery
  • No uterine tenderness
  • The fetus is alive, and fetal heart rate (FHR) is normal
Class 2: Moderate (27%)
  • Bleed seen during labour
  • Associated with uterine tetany
  • Fetal heart rate - Normal
Class 3: severe (24%)
  • Most severe
  • FHR shows distress
  • Type A- Without disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Type B - With DIC

questions.text: 40-yrs-old G3P2 obese woman with Insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus presents at 37 weeks gestation. She previously had 2 normal vaginal deliveries of babies of 3.3 and 3.5 kgs. The present estimated weight of the fetus is 3 kg by ultrasonography (USG). Her most recent HbA1c was 6.0. The patient reports that her sugars are within the normal range. Which of the following is correct about the management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient should undergo an elective cesarean section at 38 weeks to avoid shoulder dystocia

options.label: B
options.text: The patient should be induced by 38 weeks if spontaneous labour does not occur

options.label: C
options.text: After 6 weeks postpartum, the patient should undergo a 75-g glucose tolerance test

options.label: D
options.text: In the postpartum period, it is acceptable to use oral contraceptives

questions.correct_answer: B. The patient should be induced by 38 weeks if spontaneous labour does not occur
questions.explanation:
Type of diabetes Time of delivery
  • GDM controlled on diet
  • GDM requiring medication
  • Overt diabetes (controlled)
  • Overt DM (uncontrolled)
  • 40 - 41 weeks
  • 38 - 39 weeks
  • ≥ 37 wks.( max:39 weeks)
  • 34 weeks (max 37 weeks)

questions.text: A 38-year-old pregnant woman presents to the emergency at 20 weeks of gestation with breathlessness. She is diagnosed with severe mitral stenosis. The physician advises her on treatment and regular follow-up because of the risk of cardiac failure in late pregnancy. Which of the following is the best method to prevent cardiac failure in this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Balloon mitral valvuloplasty in the second trimester

options.label: D
options.text: Admit at 30 weeks to monitor and treat for failure

questions.correct_answer: B. Balloon mitral valvuloplasty in the second trimester

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with G2P1 presents to the antenatal clinic at the 20th week of gestation with a complaint of white discharge from the vagina, not associated with pain or itching. On examination, the discharge is whitish, homogenous and associated with a fishy odour. A microscopic examination shows clue cells. Which of the following is the best drug to use to treat this patient?

A 29-year-old diabetic woman, G2P1, at 34 weeks of gestation, comes to the outpatient department complaining of less fetal activities. She is on regular antenatal check-ups and takes iron and calcium pills regularly. She is nonalcoholic but smokes cigarettes occasionally, which she quit after getting pregnant. Past medical history includes hypertension for 3 years. Her ultrasound suggests fetal parameters corresponding to 29 weeks gestation. Which of the following may not be the cause for her presentation?

A 27-year-old female at 8 weeks of pregnancy presents to the OPD with complaints of excessive vomiting, nausea, and inability to tolerate orally. She also says that there is a decreased frequency of urination. Lab reports show hypochloremic alkalosis. What can be done to manage this patient?

options.label: B
options.text: Administer intravenous fluids and correct electrolyte imbalance

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer intravenous fluids and correct electrolyte imbalance

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravidity 2, presents with vaginal bleeding after 8 weeks of amenorrhea and a positive urine pregnancy test. What is the most probable cause of this clinical presentation?
questions.correct_answer: A. Chromosomal abnormality in the conceptus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman at 32 weeks of pregnancy presents with labour pains. On examination, her cervix is dilated 2 cm, and one uterine contraction is felt every 5 to 7 minutes. What is the most appropriate management of this patient?

A 30-year-old woman presents to the gynaecologist with complaints of being unable to conceive for 2 years. She is diagnosed to have anovulatory cycles. She is started on a drug that acts by antagonizing estrogenic negative feedback on the hypothalamus. She is vitally stable, and other physical examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following is true about the drug involved in a patient's pathology?

options.label: C
options.text: Significantly increases sperm counts in oligospermic men

options.label: D
options.text: 1 – 2% increase in the rate of twin pregnancy

questions.text: A primigravida presents at 33 weeks of pregnancy with complaints of swelling in bilateral feet. She states that the swelling is worst at the end of the day and subsides by morning. Her BP is 120/74 mmHg, and cardiac examination shows normal S1 and S2. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.correct_answer: B. Bed rest with feet elevation

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, presents at 7 weeks of gestation for an ultrasound evaluation. There is a single live intrauterine pregnancy of 7 weeks, adnexa is normal, and the uterus is retroverted. At what gestation may this patient start to experience urinary retention?

A 34-years-old woman presents to the Gynaecology OPD with failure to conceive after trying for the last 3 years. She has been married for 3 and a half years. On vaginal examination, there is a nodular, tender uterosacral ligament, a retroverted but normal-sized uterus, and a right adnexal mass. A recent pelvic ultrasound reveals a 6-cm right complex ovarian mass. Her CA-125 is mildly elevated. What is the initial next step in management?

A 30-year-old woman complained of excessive hair growth on her face, upper arms, and back for the past year . She mentions that her hair growth has rapidly increased over the past few months, and she also complains of hoarseness in her voice. Her abdominal ultrasound reveals an ovarian tumor. Which type of tumor is the most likely?

A 62-year-old woman in menopause complains of labia majora itching for 4 years. Topical medication has not helped much. She has started feeling soreness in the same area recently and washing has become uncomfortable. Examination reveals a hard lesion on the right labia with positive inguinal nodes. What is the most appropriate management?

options.label: C
options.text: Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid and follow up for lymph node status

questions.text: A 55-year-old lady presenting to OPD with postmenopausal bleeding for 3 months has a 1 x1cm nodule on the anterior lip of the cervix. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to be done subsequently?

A 33-year-old woman G3P2 at 34 weeks of pregnancy presents with pain in the abdomen, uterine tenderness and mild bleeding per-vaginum . Her vitals are BP 110/70, pulse 89/min and respiratory rate 18/minute. Fetal cardiac tocography (CTG) shows regular fetal heart tracing of 140bpm and no recurrent or late deacceleration. Which of the following steps is not indicated as part of the management of the underlying cause in this patient?
questions.explanation:
rostaglandin Mechanism of Action Clinical Uses Route of Administration
Prostaglandin E1 (PGE1) Vasodilation, bronchodilation, increased gastrointestinal mucus secretion Treatment of erectile dysfunction, induction of labor, ductus arteriosus closure in neonates Intravenous, Intraurethral, Intracavernosal
Prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) Vasodilation, increased uterine contractions Induction of labor, termination of pregnancy, cervical ripening prior to procedures Intravenous, Intracervical, Intrauterine
Prostaglandin F2alpha (PGF2alpha) Vasoconstriction, increased uterine contractions Induction of labor, termination of pregnancy, control of postpartum hemorrhage Intramuscular, Intravenous
Dinoprostone Synthetic PGE2 analog Induction of labor, cervical ripening Intravaginal, Intracervical
Misoprostol Synthetic PGE1 analog Prevention of gastric ulcers induced by NSAIDs, induction of labor, termination of pregnancy Oral, Intravaginal, Sublingual

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida has regular pre-natal follow-ups during her pregnancy. The fetus on serial growth ultrasound scans and antenatal doppler suggests a normally growing fetus with no signs of hypoxia. Which of the following are normal trends in fetal hematopoiesis during pregnancy?

A 28-year-old primigravida is admitted with labor pains. On electronic fetal monitoring, the heart rate appears to be 170-180 beats per minute for a sustained period of 15 minutes. Which of the following is the most common explanation for such a finding?

A 27-year-old woman presents to the fertility clinic. She has been married for 3 years and is unable to conceive. She is otherwise healthy but has delayed menstrual cycles. An ultrasound for follicle monitoring shows the absence of a developing follicle with evidence of polycystic ovaries. Which drug should be used in the first line in her next cycle for her condition?

A 40-year-old female presents with leakage of urine for the last 3 months. She has been married for 14 years and is multiparous with 4 children. Her urodynamic studies suggest stress incontinence, demonstrating urine leakage only when she is asked to cough or do a Valsalva manoeuvre. She was advised some pelvic floor exercises, but she was not relieved. Which of the following surgeries may be helpful in this condition?

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her parents, who are worried about their daughter's growth. They mention that her shoe size has not changed for the last 1.5 years. On examination by the physician, he notices a low hairline and a short and wide neck. Her arms are also turned out slightly at the elbows. He finds that her nails are spoon-shaped and small. He orders an investigation to rule out the causes of proportionate short stature. Which of the following condition is most probably the cause of her short stature?

A 10-year-old male child presents to the paediatrician with fever, vomiting, frequent bed-wetting, and constipation from the last 2 weeks. Upon examination, delayed growth and decreased energy is observed in the patient. His parents are very concerned about his growth. His blood test is sent for evaluation. Which of the following is the diagnosis of this patient? Na+ 154 K+ 4.5 HCO3 22 Osmolality 295 Urea 50 Urine specific gravity 1.005

A 10-month-old child presents to the hospital with complaints of fever, vomiting and alteration of sensorium from the last 2 weeks. Also, have a history of night wets and chills for 4 weeks. A CT brain is done, which reveals basal exudates and hydrocephalus . What is the most likely etiological agent in the condition mentioned in this case?

An 18-month-old child presented to a local subcenter with a 4-day history of fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. The child has a respiratory rate of 46 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 100 beats per minute, and a temperature of 38.5°C (101.3°F). On auscultation, there are crackles in the right lower lung zone. The oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. The child appears lethargic but is still responsive to verbal stimuli. The parents report that the child has had no prior illnesses of note and is up to date with vaccinations. A complete blood count shows a white blood cell count of 15,000/µL, with 70% neutrophils. A chest X-ray indicates an area of consolidation in the right lower lobe. What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child's condition?

options.label: A
options.text: IV antibiotics at PHC and observe

options.label: B
options.text: Give the first dose of IV antibiotics & refer to a higher centre

options.label: C
options.text: Oral amoxicillin for 5 days and send home

questions.correct_answer: B. Give the first dose of IV antibiotics & refer to a higher centre

questions.text: A newborn in a maternity hospital develops feeding difficulties and cyanosis during feeding. Physical examination reveals excessive salivation, coughing, and choking spells during feeding attempts. Medical records show that the mother of the affected baby reported experiencing polyhydramnios during her pregnancy. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube into the stomach was unsuccessful, and an abnormality is noted as shown in the chest X-ray. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: C. Esophageal atresia with tracheoesophageal fistula

questions.text: A boy aged 8 years presented at the hospital with complaints of significant pallor, exhaustion, and subconjunctival bleeding . Upon examination, enlarged supraclavicular lymph nodes were noted. A bone marrow biopsy was performed, leading to a diagnosis of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Among the following options, which is considered a good prognostic factor?
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A five-day-old, full-term male infant was severely cyanotic at birth . He had respiratory difficulty, with a respiratory rate of 65/min. On auscultation, a single loud S1 was heard . His chest X-ray showed an 'Egg-on-string' appearance. Prostaglandin E1 was administered initially, and later balloon atrial septostomy was done which showed improvement in oxygenation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this infant?

A premature newborn of 34 weeks is delivered at home . The mother had no antenatal care. The newborn is brought to the clinic after bullous lesions develop on his skin. An X-ray reveals periostitis. What should be the next investigation?
questions.correct_answer: A. VDRL for mother and baby
questions.explanation:
Congenital syphilis

Early signs of congenital syphilis:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Diffuse lymphadenopathy
  • Painful osteochondritis and periostitis (Pseudoparalysis)
  • Mucocutaneous erythematous, maculopapular rash or vesiculobullous rash
  • Followed by desquamation involving hands and feet

Late signs of congenital syphilis:

  • Olympian brow
  • Saber shins
  • Hegoumenaki sign (Enlargement of the sternal end of clavical)
  • Hutchinson's triad (Hutchison’s teeth, interstitial keratitis, sensorineural hearing loss)
  • Mulberry molars
  • Saddle nose
  • Rhagades
  • Clutton joints

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with uncontrolled diabetes mellitus presents with a complaint of ear pain (otalgia) and greenish-black discharge. On otoscopic examination, the patient has marked tenderness with multiple granulations in the external auditory canal. The culture of the discharge turns out to be Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following is the best prognostic test for the follow-up of this patient?

A 5-year-old child is brought in by his parents reporting eight episodes of acute otitis media in the last 6 months and has difficulty resolving the effusions between infections. He had low birth weight and had been on broad-spectrum antibiotics with every episode of infection. His examination along with mucus fluid in the middle ear. Further examination revealed hypertrophied adenoids. His elder brother suffered from recurrent upper respiratory tract infections leading to acute otitis media in the past. What should be done to effectively eliminate the infections?

options.label: A
options.text: Continuing treating each infection as it arises

options.label: D
options.text: Child should be operated for Adenoidectomy

questions.correct_answer: D. Child should be operated for Adenoidectomy

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a previous history of myocardial infarction presented with nasal discharge. The patient is currently on maintenance therapy for his myocardial infarction. The patient also has a history of intense itching and sneezing when gardening on his lawn. On examination, the nasal cavity has numerous polyps. Which of the following triad is present in this patient?

A 25-year-old female of low socioeconomic status visits the hospital with complaints of difficulty swallowing for the last 3 months. On physical examination, she is pale and the typical l aryngeal crepitus is absent . Which of the following conditions is characterized by the absence of laryngeal crepitus?

A 45-year-old male came to the ENT outpatient department with the complaint of ear discharge for 3 months with pain behind his eyes. The patient also has double vision. On physical examination, the vitals of the patient is within normal range. Based on the given information, which of the following is the most probable diagnosis related to the complications of the disease?
Which of the following is done in type 4 thyroplasty?

A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a complaint of epistaxis. After a series of treatments, the bleeding could not be stopped. His medical history is consistent with hypertension and diabetes. His medications include metformin and amlodipine. An attempt to block the external carotid artery is made which does not lead to resolution of the bleeding. Which of the following artery is responsible for the bleeding in this case?

An 18-year-old male presents with complaints of throat pain and difficulty swallowing. He has also experienced a change in voice. He is a non-smoker, non-alcoholic, and has never used illicit drugs. The examination findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this patient's underlying condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Tip of uvula points towards the normal side

options.label: C
options.text: Ipsilateral ear ache occurs due to referred pain via the 10th cranial nerve

options.label: D
options.text: Trismus occurs due to spasm of pterygoid muscles

questions.correct_answer: C. Ipsilateral ear ache occurs due to referred pain via the 10th cranial nerve

questions.text: A 30 years old lady who has been diagnosed with Multiple sclerosis presented with redness, blurred vision associated with floaters, and also pain in both eyes. On fundus examination, the following finding was noted (shown in the image). Your probable treatment would be?
questions.explanation: A.K. Khurana ophthalmology 7th e/p -166

questions.text: A 27-year-old male is presents to the opd with episodes of blurry vision. His intraocular pressure is 25mmhg. On slit-lamp microscopy, intermittent halos with pigmentation are seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-years-old male patient presents to the physician with complaints of transient visual obscurations for 1 week. On examination, his vision was normal and no macular oedema. The patient is otherwise vitally stable. He is an occasional smoker and smokes one pack per week. The image given below shows the fundoscopic findings. What is the best management plan for this patient regarding his current pathology?

A 30-year-old lady presents to the emergency department due to sudden severe bilateral loss of vision, more so on the right side, and with no light perception. The rest of the examination, including pupillary reflexes, fundus, and optokinetic nystagmus, is normal. She could approximate the tips of her index fingers with the right eye closed but not with the left eye closed. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient came to eye OPD with disc-shaped edema over the cornea and a history of vesicles over lips a few weeks back. There is no ulcer on the staining. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after being suddenly hit by a ball in the left eye. He complained of pain and redness in the left eye. He is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. On ocular examination, there was no perforation of the eyeball, and there was no intraocular foreign body. Which of the following investigation should be done in this case?

A forty-five year old man presents to your clinic with the complaint of gradually progressive, painless diminution of vision in both eyes for 3 months. Slit-lamp examination of the eyes shows an anterior subcapsular cataract, and the patient is scheduled for a cataract removal surgery. The surgery is complicated by the rupture of the posterior capsule. All of the following complications can be expected in this patient due to rupture of the posterior capsule, except?

A 27-year-old, 38 weeks pregnant woman with a height of 130 cm and a weight of 51 kg diagnosed with cephalopelvic disproportion with fetal distress has been admitted for the emergency cesarean section. A lower segment cesarean section is performed, and a live male infant of 1.8 kg with an APGAR of 8/9 is delivered. Which of the following would be expected in the eyes of the newborn ?

A 1-month-old baby presents a 2-week history of a red, slightly raised plaque on the left forehead, periorbital area, and malar cheek with a rim of vasoconstriction around it. A similar image of the lesion from another case is given below: The lesion has been thickening each day per mm. What is the next best step in management?

A 45-year-old Asian male presents to the dermatologic clinic for the evaluation of a lesion on the right sole of the foot. He states that the lesion has been present for the past many years, but now it seems to be enlarging . On examination, irregular, hyperpigmented plaque on his right sole is seen as shown below: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Superficial spreading melanomas Nodular melanomas Lentigo maligna melanoma Acral lentiginous melanoma
Younger patients (median age: 5th decade) Slightly older patients than SSM (median age: 7th decade) Elderly patient (median age 8th decade)  
Involve intermittently sun-exposed anatomical sites such as the trunk, back, and extremities. Occur at any location Chronically sun-exposed cutaneous sites such as the head and neck region or forearm Acral sites are the palms, soles, and subungual regions.
Present as a flat, slowly growing irregular lesion with variegated pigmentation that enlarges in a radial manner unless dermal invasion supervenes; this is usually signified clinically by the presence of a raised area. Present as a rapidly expanding nodule that may show ulceration and hemorrhage. Clinically they may be confused with other cutaneous tumors such as basal cell carcinomas, particularly if they are amelanotic. Presents as a large, variegated pigmented macule with irregular edges, parts of which may become raised if dermal invasion supervenes. Present as slowly growing, variegated pigmented macules

Histologically -

Intra epidermal - large pleomorphic epithelioid melanocyte showing nested and single cell upward migration (Pagetoid epidermal invasion)

Histologically -

No epidermal component extending beyond the edges of the dermal component (a “cut off” of three rete ridges is used by some authors)

Histologically -

The lentiginous proliferation of atypical melanocytes in severely sun-damaged skin, occasional multinucleate or giant melanocytes, confluent lentiginous growth, nesting, and pagetoid epidermal invasion.

Histologically -

Single atypical melanocytes scattered along the junctional epidermal layer, associated lymphocytic infiltrate partly obscuring the dermo-epidermal junction can be a useful diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a complaint of fever for the past day. His mother states that her child has also developed multiple skin lesions on the face and upper extremities . On examination, the following lesions are noted as shown below: Microscopic examinatio n of the skin lesions shows neutrophilic and histiocytic infiltration in the dermis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old patient with a family history of allergy presents with a rapidly evolving red rash involving the back of knees and wrists. Histopathological examination of the skin shows a finding known as spongiosis, as shown in the image below. Is it characterized by one of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Retention of nuclei in stratum corneum
